newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: DUTCH MONEY MARKET DEALERS AWAIT NEW PACT.
newsitem.headline: DUTCH MONEY MARKET DEALERS AWAIT NEW PACT.

text.p: Dutch money market dealers were somewhat divided on a possible rise of the Dutch special advances rate this afternoon when the central bank sets a new pact since the guilder slipped further against the mark.
Dealers said business was slow while participants were awaiting the Dutch central bank decision on the special advances on Thursday afternoon at 1400 GMT.
The Dutch special advances is currently pegged at 3.00 percent, equal to the German repo rate. Some dealers expected an independent rate rise in the Netherlands on guilder weakness.
The guilder was trading at 112.689 per 100 marks at 1230 GMT versus 112.625 on Wednesday, but dealers said the Dutch currency had been even weaker earlier today.

"The guilder is weaker than it had been before," said one dealer, adding the current fixing might be more in balance with the current economic circumstances. "I do not foresee that the Dutch central bank will raise the special advances on this as we only follow Germany," said another dealer.
Earlier today the Bundesbank indicated it would not make a statement on its intentions for next week's repo auction.
This relieved the market as some had not been excluding a rate move in Germany as the dollar had been heading higher recently versus the mark and other European currencies.
Another dealer said he expected a rise of the advances rate by 10 basis points.
"And then we still have to see if it supports the guilder, but I do not see there is space for a stronger rise," he said.
A quick ring round among money market dealers resulted in more "no rise" then "yes there will be a rise" opinions, but most said there was little certainty around in the market.
"Let's say that 25 percent of us expect a rise and the other 75 percent not," said one dealer.
All money rates were stable with call money trading at 3.18 percent bid and three-month deposits at 3.36 percent bid.
